instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRDGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRDGD? This is a typo of . When you see ALL_SYS_PWRDGD, assume they meant to type .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.P5VS4RS3_PGOOD: What is P5VS4RS3_PGOOD? P5VS4RS3_PGOOD is a signal that confirms the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail is working properly. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, in S0 state, no fan spin
threads.message:
Green light on charger/ goes to orange.
No fan spin.
No liquid damage.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>: 4.95V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>: 3.30 V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>: 1.5 V

<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>: 0V at pin 1 <CAPACITOR>C2700</CAPACITOR>

<CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
PIN 13 was 0.18V to ground in diode mode but ONLY 336 Ohms in Resistance mode
All the other pins (except ground pins of course) were in the kO range in resistance mode.

<CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
PIN 13: 1.2V

L7430: 1.2V pin 2

I assumed I was in S0 state.


Is there a short on PIN 13 <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>? It seems like very low resistance to ground and I'm not sure if
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> should be 0 V


<TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> also looks not good:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, in S0 state, no fan spin
threads.message:
You can leave <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> out of board.
But shouldn't be the culprit, if <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> stays high.

Do you get VCORE?
<SIGNAL>MEMVTT_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is required to enable  <SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, in S0 state, no fan spin
threads.message: You mean change <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, in S0 state, no fan spin
threads.message:
NO.
Is a redundant protection, not really needed...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, in S0 state, no fan spin
threads.message:
At the same moment  when <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL>  is high, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> must appear too, if you remove any other component from its rail; apart of <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR>, of course.
As I said, let <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> out of board and test again.
<CHIP>U1845</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> and SMC are connected there too.

Remove all, apart of <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR> and SMC.

threads.message:

So is time to get it.
Be sure to get voltage on all other big coils first, including page 57.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, in S0 state, no fan spin
threads.message:
replace

<RESISTOR>R8165</RESISTOR> ---->FAN SPIN GONE <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> GONE
<RESISTOR>R8166</RESISTOR> --> FAN SPIN GONE & <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL>-PWRGD GONE


please note that with all resistors off

PIN 1 <RESISTOR>R8165</RESISTOR>= 0.1V ---><SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_PGOOD</SIGNAL>
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is also 0.1V

<CHIP>U7820</CHIP>
PIN 2: 3.33V
3:0.1V  (not short to ground)
6: 0.8 V   ----> should be 1.8V (not short to ground)
8:1.8V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, in S0 state, no fan spin
threads.message:
"6: 0.8 V   ----> should be 1.8V"
Do not make wrong assumptions; pin 6 is connected to a resistor divider (feedback signal)!
There is also noted a formula where you can get the exact voltage of pin 6; yes, is 0.8V.

<RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR> also serves as pull-up resistor for all power good signals connected to <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
When you disconnect one resistor, what do you expect to get at its "left" side???

I saw several times failing 1V8 power good signal.
The board should work without <RESISTOR>R8165</RESISTOR>, if you get 1V8 power rail correctly; even if its power good is not OK.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, in S0 state, no fan spin
threads.message:
i lose fan spin when i replace

<RESISTOR>R8165</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R8166</RESISTOR>

Should i be losing fan spin as i replace the pwrgd resistors?

As the resistors went in <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> went away.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> seems to get pulled down when i replace either of the resistors which is strange because wouldnt that mean 2 power rails have issues.

P1V8S3
P5VS4RS3

That may be a faulty asumption. I was assuming that the <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> signal must stay present as each rail is re-connected.

Again i think i may be not understanding the logic there.

[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.it-tech.com.au/mac-q-a/macbook-logic-board-power-rails/[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, in S0 state, no fan spin
threads.message:
The resistors are good, no need to replace them.

Don't you get fan spin removing only <RESISTOR>R8166</RESISTOR>?
This is what I understood before...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, in S0 state, no fan spin
threads.message:
Maybe I explained wrong

SEQUENCE
Remove <RESISTOR>R8166</RESISTOR>   ----> NO FAN SPIN
Remove <RESISTOR>R8165</RESISTOR>    ----> NO FAN SPIN
Remove <RESISTOR>R8164</RESISTOR>    ----> NO FAN SPIN
Remove <RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR>     ----> NO FAN SPIN

At this point all of the above resistors are off this board

Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> -------> FAN SPIN


The only thing that makes the damn fan spin is removing <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and... <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is back

Put back <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> ----> NO FAN SPIN
Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>  -----> FAN SPIN

So lets put back <RESISTOR>R8166</RESISTOR> with <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> off the board?  -----> FAN stops spinning

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, in S0 state, no fan spin
threads.message:
I said you can throw <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>.
You have a problem with resistor dividers on its inputs.
But this chip is not really needed, just a redundant protection.
Resolder the other resistors, without <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>.

<RESISTOR>R8164</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R8165</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R8166</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR>

The fan, as I said above, goes away.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>....goes to 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, in S0 state, no fan spin

You MUST put back resistors one by one.
See when the fan stops spinning...
